question: What products fit in the same category?
we_want: Plates? Forks? Milk Bottle? Reusable Napkins?

question: What are the cost implications?
we_are: Each spoon costs $6.60 to make and is sold for $15. So each spoon makes a profit.
we_want: The pricing structure can remain the same as the spoon for the first $5000 in sales i.e. double the cost to sell the item. Then the pricing structure can be modified based on customers’ response and the market status.

question: What obstacles you’d face (funding, expansion, storage)?
we_are: Investor funding has allowed BabyStoon to expand triple in size.
we_want: Keep the company small so the product quality remains intact.

question: What obstacles you’d face (funding, expansion, storage)?
we_are: Investor funding has allowed BabyStoon to expand triple in size.
we_want: Keep the company small so the product quality remains intact.
went_point: Do not want to become a corporation affecting the materials used to build the product. So storage is going to be okay.
But this means we would have to find investors who are willing to be okay with our values.
If we don’t have an investor who wants to try small businesses like ours, the pricing structure can be modified to only make on-demand products with shipping & handling set accordingly.

question: How much money can be made with this product?
we_are: Spoons make an average annual revenue of $1,500,000 with 10% profit margin.
we_want: Keep the same goal of an average annual revenue of $1,500,000 with 10% profit margin in 7 years time.
